title: General election: Lib Dems in 'Remain Alliance' talks with Greens and Plaid Cymru
text:

The Lib Dems are in talks with two anti-Brexit parties over whether to step aside in certain seats in a Remain alliance.

Leader Jo Swinson confirmed they are talking to Plaid Cymru and the Green Party ahead of the general election in a bid to maximise the Remain vote.

Separately, Ms Swinson also did not explicitly rule out a coalition-style deal with the Tories or Labour to keep them in power if the December 12 poll leaves a hung parliament.

But her colleague Sir Ed Davey confirmed: "With Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson , who are both unfit to be Prime Minister, the Liberal Democrats will not do a coalition or any sort of arrangement with them.

"We’re going in to win this election. Because we believe we need to stop Brexit to get our country back on track.”

Previously parties have pulled out of specific election seats so votes can unite around a single Remain candidate - the best way to win under the UK's first-past-the-post system.

(Image: PA)

Ms Swinson said last night: “There will be some places where a party like Plaid Cymru and the Greens might have a stronger chance”.

Sir Ed added: "We have been discussing with Plaid and with Greens who both share our view that we need to stop Brexit."

Saying the Lib Dems "want to see if there’s things we can do with them", he added: "We will look to see if we can work with them to make sure we can defeat Boris Johnson and defeat the Labour Party.

"Before the election we will have some discussions, they are already ongoing, and we’ll see the fruits of those shortly, with Plaid and with the Green Party."

Separately the Lib Dems have faced questions over whether they could prop up Labour or the Tories after the election if there is a hung Parliament.

Questioned this morning, Ms Swinson did not explicitly rule it out.

Asked if she was ruling out supporting either Mr Johnson or Mr Corbyn as prime minister, Ms Swinson told the BBC: "I can't be clearer.

"Neither Boris Johnson nor Jeremy Corbyn is fit to be prime minister.

"Our country deserves a better choice, and I am standing as candidate to be prime minister.”

Asked if she would be prepared to enter into some kind of informal deal with the Tories or Labour without those two men at the helm, she said: “Both of those parties as currently configured are parties that want to force through Brexit on our country.

"It's going to be bad for our country. And they both have that shared vision for the future. The Liberal Democrats have a different positive alternative vision for the future."

However, Sir Ed ruled out a coalition or deal in an almost simultaneous appearance on BBC Breakfast. And Lib Dem MP Layla Moran said: "Yep. Let’s make this clear from now."
description: Jo Swinson said there are some places where certain Remain parties might have a stronger chance
